Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Role of Grain Boundary Character in Corrosion Behavior: Linking Atomic Scale Interfacial Structure to Precipitation and Failure Mechanisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to develop an understanding of the atomic scale grain boundary structure dependence of corrosion enhancing precipitation in fcc metals. Corrosion has a devastating effect on many industries, including nuclear, naval ship structures, and off-shore wind turbines. Grain boundary engineering has been shown to improve boundary dependent properties including creep, intergranular stress corrosion, embrittlement, and fatigue. However, questions remain about the anisotropic nature of both the segregation and precipitation relevant to all sensitization dependent failure in fcc materials. This project will focus on understanding the dependence of grain boundary structure on the precipitation that causes corrosion damage. The results generated from this study will serve as a predictive tool for developing future alloys resistant to deleterious intergranular precipitation in extreme environments. The work will use an experimental approach to analyze the combined effects temperature, environment, and grain boundary type on corrosion-causing precipitation mechanisms, which will ultimately yield a clearer understanding of corrosion in a wide range of alloys.

This research is expected to advance the fundamental understanding of mechanisms of fcc metal failure under corrosion, one of the most important structural materials in use today. Philadelphia has ~80% minority student population, so the opportunity to bring underrepresented groups into STEM fields is enormous. The PI plans to develop a program, named "TURBINE" (Transforming Underrepresented Research Basis in Engineering), for local high school minority and female students to learn about future careers in energy-related fields to spur an interest in research and development and engineering education/training for a future economy both in Philadelphia and globally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES

 

Overview.

The focus of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award was to develop an understanding of the atomic scale grain boundary (GB) structure dependence of corrosion enhancing precipitation, and its local and global effects, in fcc metals. Corrosion plays a devastating role in many industries, including the nuclear, defense, and energy sectors. While processing of fcc metals by methods such as grain boundary engineering (GBE) have seen success in mitigating GB-dependent failure, including creep, intergranular stress corrosion, embrittlement, and fatigue, questions remain about the anisotropic nature of segregation and precipitation leading to this damage. Thus, the project focused on understanding the dependence of the precipitation that causes corrosion damage grain boundary structure using an experimental approach to analyze the combined effects temperature, environment, and grain boundary type on corrosion-causing precipitation mechanisms. A multiscale approach was taken, ranging from bulk processing and corrosion studies to localized, high resolution structural analysis correlated with grain boundary segregation, precipitation, and damage. The results generated from this study serve as a predictive tool for developing future alloys resistant to deleterious intergranular precipitation in extreme environments.

Intellectual Merit.

Results produced from the proposed work were instrumental in developing a clear connection between the microstructural evolution and resulting structures associated with grain boundary engineering, known as twin related domains (TRDs), their character, and degradation. Using iterative processing coupled with nodal analysis from SEM/EBSD techniques, a mechanism for TRD growth and propagation as a function of local dislocation density, level of strain, and starting microstructure was yielded. In grain boundary engineered microstructures with large TRD populations, analysis of individual grain boundaries, using site-specific techniques developed within the framework of this project, uncovered a significant dependence of precipitation and subsequent corrosion on coherent sigma 3s, and perhaps more surprisingly, a lack of dependence on other types of coincidence site lattice boundaries (sigma 9, 27, etc.). Importantly, sigma 3 boundaries were shown to be “recoverable” throughout the grain boundary engineering process. Ultimately, it was shown that the TRD size was critical in determining corrosion resistance, however it should be noted that the size of the TRD with respect to the total sample/specimen size was critical for the outcome in a corrosive environment.

 

Broader Impact.  Technologically, this results of this proposal have far reaching implications on the performance of structural materials in corrosive environments. Educationally, the PI championed participation of minority and female students in STEM fields through the Drexel WINS (Women in Nuclear Science) program, at the K-12 level through ASM Materials Camp, Philly Materials Day, and a partnership with the Science Leadership Academy-Beeber. Specifically, the project funded two undergraduates to perform research on materials in extreme environments, and introduced countless young women and students from the Philadelphia School District to related science.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2017
Modified by: Mitra Taheri
